reviewText:
This is a difficult game for me to review.

Unfinished is an interesting short game. You play as an unfinished drawing who wants to be complete.
The game serves as an effective metaphor for the creative process in general: everyone who has tried to create something, be it art, writing, a game, or whatever, can recognise the story this game tries to tell.

The art style is great. All hand-drawn, and it stays this throughout. The art is accompanied by soothing music.
The narrative is told through voice over -- sadly no subtitles -- that is clear, if at a little low volume compared to the music.

Gameplay wise, you walk through white, empty environments to find body parts (different legs, different bodies, different heads), all of which give you enhanced abilities. As you progress the levels become more... drawn.

Unfortunately Unfinished is hard to get in to. I was stuck at the first real puzzle for far too long, since the game didn't make it clear at all that I could swap abilities in mid-air, and I only found this by chance.
It is also short. Too short perhaps for Steam refunds. If I hadn't gotten stuck at the  beginning I could've finished it within 30 minutes.

While a bit rough the game is mechanically sound and the story resonates with me, as a fellow (want to be?) creator.

As for the price point, €5 is perhaps steep for such a short game, and (disclaimer) I didn't buy it for that price: I had a 50% off coupon. At that price level (€2,50 or less) I can recommend it to everyone.

Just don't be a ♥♥♥♥ and refund it after you've finished your speed run, okay?

reviewText:
A short preface: I had received a free copy of the game for submitting my artwork in for the game before release, but that does not affect my overall opinion of the game.

Summary (TL;DR)
I was very impressed with this games message, and how well it conveyed the story of a character you never see. You play as one of the narrators unfinished sketches who becomes self aware and goes on a journey to figure himself out. Along the way, you gain powerups that help you finish the levels and make the travel easier.

While this game was short, I enjoyed my time playing this.

You can view a gallery of all the entries here:
http://www.fromdustscratch.com/2015/08/unfinished-an-artists-lament-unfinished-sketches-from-other-artists/

Pros    Great narration
Decent graphics
Great Story
Has Steam Trading Cards
Great music
Features artwork from 25 unknown artists (including myself)
Neutral Points    One of my pieces was featured and credited in this game.
Came out of Steam Greenlight
Cons    Very short story
Short soundtrack
A few minor physic errors
Game crashed once before the ending, making me have to redo level 5
Few minor graphical errors on level 4.
Narration can get repetitive if you do not finish levels fast
Controls take a little bit to get used to.
Rating6/10

reviewText:
What if your dreams, ideas, and creations all had a life of their own? One of man's most greatest abilities is to create, rather that be life, tools, or art. Sometimes though, creation isn't easy, sometimes things are left undone, inspiration is a valuable commodity that doesn't come easy. You will explore these concepts and more in this interesting and entertaining puzzle game. You play an unfinished doodle, who seeks identity in a world of art and chaos. The story is shared between Artist and Doodle as they both go through a journey of discovering themselves and purpose. While Unfinished - An Artist's Lament is a rather short game, what it does have to offer is extremely enjoyable aesthetically and gameplay follows suit. Finding unfinished drawings, you add abilities to your own drawing, such as spring boots, helicopter hat and other whimsical powers. The puzzles in Unfinsihed are rather simple, the game never draws focus away from what matters, the story. This leads the game to feeling like its full of good ideas but ends rather suddenly. While this was obviously intended, a part of me couldn't help but wonder what else could've been had the ideas and powers/levels been expanded upon. Nevertheless Unfinished - An Artist's Lament is a journey of self actualization that is fun, pleasant, and makes you ponder your own creations and goals that you never quite completed. This game is a fine example of Gamer Art and should be treated and enjoyed as such.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/MPM95T3SuEc
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

reviewText:
You're an unfinished sketch and must try to reach the pencil of your creator to finally know who you were meant to be: to do this you'll gather a few powers (such as helicopter cap, running or jumping shoes etc) and use them to traverse the few levels that make up the game.
While a surely interesting concept Unfinished sadly offers a very bland and short gameplay experience, one that not even its few memorable moments can save.

PROS:

-simple but effective art style

-one level (pictured in the screenshot) is truly gorgeout to look at, original in its design and serves as the game's most enjoyable point

NEUTRAL:

-story is a bit of a mixed bag as a few genuinely interesting ideas are brought down by an equal amount of dull exposition

CONS:

-platforming sections are generally dull, some can get quite frustrating aswell

-movement and camera controls feel awkward

-most levels feel a bit too barren as they lack any kind of detail

-at times it can be hard to understand where you're supposed to go

-standard movement speed is fairly slow

-just as its Store pages say it's quite short (I'd say 45 minutes)

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=572725244

I took a few days off before finally reviewing this game as I had conflicting feelings about it...I see it's been created as a work of love and the theme is plainly dear to the dev, some of the art is also truly nice. Sadly as an actual game Unfinished really falls flat as the bland levels and barebones gameplay take their toll on the player: I just didn't have much fun using the awkward controls to switch powers at the right time or to try and aim my jumps correctly to move through a few platforms.

The gameplay simply isn't refined enough to be engaging and there's not enough to do to make up for its problems: most levels look and feel the same and the new powers you'll unlock don't do much to mix things up, you'll just be moving forward, jump and/or float a bit until you reach a new zone, rinse and repeat.

It's a real shame as the game can be quite enjoyable when it drops the dull platforming and leaves you to explore a bit while giving some narration, the fact it does so while introducing some vibrant colours into a mostly black and white world also helps tremendously in making these moments shine. Sadly this happens basically only once and it simply isn't enough to make up for the rest of the game.

reviewText: Simple but effective, and pretty much aimed at artists.\n\nIf you're in the business of creating things, it's quite easy to relate to the story being told. There's a few I know that feeling" moments
date: and that's really what the game is designed for I think.\n\nIt's not going to blow your mind with indepth mechanics. Not a Hardcore platformer etc. But if you're having an artblock
recommended: feeling a little down on your skills or whatever?\nYeah why not

reviewText: This game is short...  about 30 minutes long, possibly pushed to an hour if you have a difficult time with the mechanics.  It is not really even a game.  It is a walking (and bouncing) simulator where you hear an artist complain that he is out of ideas and that people do not like his work, all while you try to wander over to a pencil.  That's it.  There is no story, there are no enemies, and there are just a couple of puzzles (if you count stacking blocks as puzzles).  You do get a few power-ups, but they are difficult and clunky at best.\n\nI will say this though: I did enjoy the music.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disclosure: I was provided a review code for this game.

My Quick Look on Unfinished - An Artist's Lament
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uJdWrsjUnQo

I beat this game in 30 minutes.  It's *very short*, overbearing in its delivery, initially obtuse, yet there are a few moments when this game shines.  Here is a gif of my favorite moment in the game:

http://i.imgur.com/ot0R1js.gifv

There is this moment and a few others where everything the game is trying to do succeeds.  Other times, the purpose of explaining an Artist's anxieties can become overbearing.  And I'm honestly not sure if I'm supposed to be critiquing that as a fault of the game or if that is the purpose of the game's design.

I like the game.  I like that it was attempted.  There are parts that were inspiring and there were parts that were annoying.  The very beginning of the game is the definition of obtuse.  Is it obtuse on purpose?  Is that frustration I'm feeling *supposed* to happen?

If it was, well then job well done!  If it wasn't, well then, that part could have been done better.

Still, I like short games and Unfinished, with all of it's faults, still left a positive impression on me.

reviewText: Overall, it's a nice, fun game.  You play as a simple, unfinished sketch.  While chasing the pencil of the person who designed you, you hear the story of your creator, and the trouble he's going through.  It's got a good message, and while it can get a little laggy, most of it runs pretty smoothly.  I've played it twice, and truly enjoyed each time.  It didn't take long to get attached to the cute sketch you play as.  I'd definately recommed this game.

reviewText: I really wanted to love this game, I love the concept. The concept and art sold me. However, I couldn't stomach the incredibly slow walking speed of the character. You're forced to walk incredibly slow, and it doesn't seem like any consideration was given to the physics of the character- how it moves, specifically. Just flat, boring, WASD walking through miles of endless white. And you don't really jump either- you select a bouncing" power up and bounce constantly to get over obstacles. I did not find this mechanic fun or intuitive- just annoying and slow like the walking.\n\nGreat concept and art
date: frustratingly slow and plain controls. I didn't want to force myself through the boring process of moving my character around to getting the final message or metaphor of the experience- I just wanted it to end."

reviewText:
So true. There is a lot of stress and efforts to put into one creative work.
Some people don't value artists and just want them to finish their work early for their own good.
Long ago I supported cracked games, but since I learned about all the hardworks from the game developers, like now, I buy the games instead of downloading a cracked game. Luckily, I found steam. Steam sales a lot of games at reasonable prices.

Remember, if you support a creative work, don't copy paste or reupload the work to somewhere else.
You can see people reupload someone else's videos and images illegally. Mostly in Facebook that allowed copyrighted content to be posted with minor changes.

I really like how YouTube prevents copyrighted materials. Their system is really supporting the creator of the creative works.

I did enjoy this game a lot, I played through it about 3-4 times now, but I cannot recommend this game.

Positives:
- Good story line and music, great atmosphere and a fresh way of story telling to the player.
(I love how the music begins to become a whole piece" after the passing the first wall.)
- Platforming puzzles add depth to the game
date:
creating a feeling of wanting to become "finished".
- Great narrative prompts to player.

Negatives:
- The music is a BIG part of this game
recommended: but if you get stuck it becomes annoying VERY quickly.\n(At the beginning and on the last level there is a high pitched sound
hoursPlayed: and the music is on loop)\nMuting takes away a lot away from the game.\n- JPEG instruction sheet is not enough
voteText: a beginning tutorial at the start to understand how the game works would be infinitely better.\n- Controls are a bit clunky. (Cannot hit 1-3 while moving to select a different item
helpfulPercent: must ONLY be pressing 1-3 at that time)\n- Game forces player to admire artwork or listen to storytelling at some points
votesTotal: but given the context that this game is a platformer it was done in such a way that it became more annoying rather than adding value to the story.\n\nOverall I think there are a lot of improvements that can be made to the game. The length of the game is perfect. It just needs some more polish. Thanks for making this Andrew I liked a lot of your ideas!"

reviewText: Fun short game, good story and music. High on charm and love the hand drawn art style. Made by the same developer as Drew and the Floating Labyrinth although not as long (Game is only ~30 minutes long). If you enjoyed Drew you will enjoy this game and likewise if you liked this game you might want to check out Drew :)

Game is interesting and worth playing if you manage to follow this game's logic.

Puzzles it not what you should be playing for, see this game more as an experience and puzzles are just in the way of experiencing it all at once. That's why I think this game should have been 100% walking simulator, not just 50% as it came out to be.

Looks good, cute music, interesting story/experience.

The bad is that I couldn't find any graphic options except for some shadow settins, and the introduction of new game mechanics is poor. Also no subtitles.

Game is very short, think twice before buying if you don't have a job or can't afford to spend 5$ on a very short experience.

There is a demo outside of Steam, try it before buying.
http://steamcommunity.com/app/388680/discussions/0/541907867761968494/

To developer, try a full narrative experience next time and make the game longer. With better game options and easier to understand game mechanic introduction if it has some puzzle/platformer/exploration elements.

A platformer that tells a story any professional artist will resonate with. For an indie its good, the controls can be a bit wonky as you can not move and select body parts at the same time. The only time this was an issue was the first level, but overall a good experience. Also the voice acting  and music can get repetitive if you get stuck, annoying but didn't diminish my enjoyment. I do recomend this, and if you work in a creative field it will be relatable.

This Isnt The Next Isaac But Its A Really Good Game (NOTE I GOT IT CHEAP AT CON BRAVO SO I MIGHT BE BIASED) Its Fun And Has A Nice Story This Game Is Overall Just Great - From That Red Head At Conbravo

The story's pretty nifty, and the art style is neat. That in mind, the gameplay is just some really simple puzzle platforming. It's not bad, but nothing special. Get this if you're looking for a neat story about art, not for a fun or challenging platformer.
